sn12.62:4.2: “Mendicants, when it comes to this body made up of the four elements, an uneducated ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
sn12.62:4.4: This body made up of the four elements is seen to increase and diminish, to be taken up and laid to rest.
sn12.62:4.5: That’s why, when it comes to this body, an uneducated ordinary person might become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
sn12.62:4.6: But when it comes to that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’, an uneducated ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, or freed.
sn12.62:4.8: Because for a long time they’ve been attached to it, thought of it as their own, and mistaken it:
sn12.62:4.9: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn12.62:4.10: That’s why, when it comes to this mind, an uneducated ordinary person is unable to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed.
sn12.62:5.1: But an uneducated ordinary person would be better off taking as self this body made up of the four elements, rather than the mind.
sn12.62:5.3: This body made up of the four elements is seen to last for a year, or for two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or a hundred years, or even longer.
sn12.62:5.4: But that which is called ‘mind’ or ‘sentience’ or ‘consciousness’ arises as one thing and ceases as another all day and all night.
sn12.62:6.1: In this case, a learned noble disciple carefully focuses on sources in the context of dependent origination itself:
sn12.62:6.2: ‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.
sn12.62:6.3: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
sn12.62:6.4: Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
sn12.62:6.5: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.
sn12.62:6.6: Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
sn12.62:6.7: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.
sn12.62:6.8: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
sn12.62:6.9: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.
sn12.62:7.1: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced.
sn12.62:7.2: But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops.
sn12.62:7.3: In the same way, pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
sn12.62:7.4: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.
sn12.62:7.6: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
sn12.62:7.7: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.
sn12.62:8.1: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn12.62:8.2: Being disillusioned they become dispassionate. Being dispassionate they’re freed. When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn12.62:8.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
